title: 106_s1709
content: The Act is titled "State Criminal Alien Assistance Program II and Local Medical Emergency Reimbursement Act". It includes the "State Criminal Alien Assistance Program II Act of 1999" and outlines findings and purposes. Congress finds that federal policies along the southwest border impact illegal immigration, states and local governments were partially reimbursed for incarcerating criminal aliens in fiscal year 1996, with an increase in jurisdictions applying for reimbursement in subsequent years. The University of Arizona study in January 1998 found that counties on Arizona's border with Mexico, such as Santa Cruz and Cochise, bear a disproportionate burden from criminal illegal aliens. For example, Santa Cruz County had 12.7% of the border population but accounted for 50% of alien crossings and 32.5% of illegal alien apprehensions in 1998. Santa Cruz County spent $1.9 million out of its $5 million criminal justice budget in fiscal year 1998 on dealing with this issue. In Santa Cruz County, $1.9 million was spent to process criminal illegal aliens, with over half not reimbursed by Federal monies. Despite appeals to Federal and State officials, relief from this burden has not been obtained. Border counties in Texas bore unreimbursed costs for apprehension, prosecution, and other services for criminal aliens serving time in county jails. Nonborder counties in Texas also faced similar unreimbursed costs for criminal aliens in county jails. The State of Texas incurred substantial unreimbursed costs for law enforcement efforts due to criminal illegal aliens. The Federal Government should reimburse States for the related costs of imprisoning illegal aliens. The purpose of this title is to provide financial assistance to States and local communities for expenditures related to illegal juvenile aliens and to ensure equitable treatment for affected States. The purpose of this title is to provide financial assistance to States and local communities for expenditures related to illegal juvenile aliens and to ensure equitable treatment for affected States and local governments affected by Federal policies on curbing illegal immigration and criminal alien activity on the southwest border. SEC. 103. REIMBURSEMENT OF STATES FOR INDIRECT COSTS RELATED TO INCARCERATION OF ILLEGAL ALIENS. Section 501 of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include reimbursement for costs incurred by states for imprisoning illegal aliens or Cuban nationals convicted of a felony, as well as indirect costs such as court expenses, indigent defense, and probation costs. Authorization of $200,000,000 appropriations for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 to carry out subsection (a)(2). SEC. 104. REIMBURSEMENT OF STATES FOR COSTS OF INCARCERATING JUVENILE ALIENS. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include provisions regarding juvenile aliens who have been adjudicated delinquent or committed to a correctional facility by a State or locality. The term 'juvenile alien' is defined as an alien who has been through the juvenile justice system. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include reporting on illegal juvenile aliens committed to State or local juvenile correctional facilities. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include reporting on juvenile aliens under section 501. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to provide reimbursement to states bordering Mexico or Canada for emergency health services to undocumented aliens. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to provide reimbursement to states bordering Mexico or Canada for emergency health services to undocumented aliens. For fiscal years 2002 through 2005, $200,000,000 is available for allotments to certain states based on the number of undocumented aliens. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to provide reimbursement to states bordering Mexico or Canada for emergency health services to undocumented aliens. For fiscal years 2002 through 2005, $200,000,000 is available for allotments to certain states based on estimates of the resident illegal alien population residing in each State prepared by the Statistics Division of the Immigration and Naturalization Service as of October 1992. The amount of allotment not paid out under subsection (c) shall be available for payment during the subsequent fiscal year. The Secretary will pay amounts to each State for emergency health services to undocumented aliens based on State plans submitted, taking into account payments under the Social Security Act for emergency medical services. The Secretary will pay amounts to each State for emergency health services provided to undocumented aliens by eligible local governments, hospitals, and related providers, with special consideration for those in border counties or areas with a high concentration of undocumented aliens. Providers are considered "related" to a hospital if they furnish emergency health services. The provider furnishes emergency health services to an individual for whom the hospital also furnishes emergency health services. Amounts paid under this subsection shall not duplicate payments made under title XIX of the Social Security Act for the provision of emergency medical services. Definitions include hospital, provider, and Secretary. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and the term "State" refers to the 50 States and the District of Columbia. $200,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005 for this section.
